content.description:
Originally intended as somewhat of a warm-up for

Belays of Glory

, but turned out to be a fun outing in itself.

Except for the first say 5 feet, the stone on this route is immaculate. The position is unique.

Sweet Tides follows a prow of sorts with a few tricky cruxes that graze the 5.11 mark especially if you are shorter. The technical crux is around the second to third bolt, but the moves cranking through the last few clips give a surprising little pump!
content.location: First route at the top of the trail in the middle of the crag. You can't miss it. See photo.

content.description: This is an obvious line through large section of quality, clean granite on Mourning Glory Wall.  Start with fun, 5.10 climbing up to the first small overhang, and traverse right underneath roof through first crux on a thin seam into technical face climbing.  Head right under and through second roof, again keeping right.  This is airy and exposed.
content.location:
Head under the huge roof of

Mourning Glory

on the narrow ledge until the ledge gets much wider near a small dead tree. This is the second route past

Mourning Glory

on the vertical wall.

content.description:
Climb the first 5 bolts of

Pandora's Blue Sharpie

, then head left up the clean, orange, vertical face. Hard moves on crimps lead to a jug. Finish with a boulder problem through the roof.
content.location:
Start as for

Pandora's Blue Sharpie

.

climbs.name: Mourning Glory
climbs.fa: D. Mabe, May 2009, FFA: D. Woods, March 2012

content.description:
Call in the

Young Guns

....

Start on cool belay ledge, after scrambling a short section of white quartz. A bolt on either end of the ledge intended for a dogline.

Open with an elegant traversing sequence for the first three bolts (12-) and then cruise up a ledgy ramp to the start of the ceiling. 6 draws are hanging from this 35 foot overhang. I count about 3-4 hard cruxes, with the hardest part being a burly contorted boulder-problem getting established into the ceiling. You can expect powerful, dynamic, long moves all the way to the chains. The movement on it is awesome. The stone is incredible.

EDIT:

route was freed by Daniel Woods, 3/20/12, 5.14c/d

, and dubbed "Mourning Glory".

Enjoy and good luck.
content.protection:
11 bolts and chains anchor.

Currently I have fixed draws on all but the first one.
content.location:
You can't miss it once you are up there.

Scramble 4th class for about 15 feet up a quartz-step to the belay ledge.

content.description: From a belay ledge with a bolt, scramble up easy rock to the first bolt 15 feet above. Clip three bolts and then get ready to boulder V9/10 compression. This deposits you at the glory hole no hands rest. Now traverse up and right with your feet just above the hanging arete with huge exposure. Very cool indeed.
content.location:
Start on a belay ledge up and left of the start to

Mourning Glory

. There is a bolt on the ledge from which to belay.

content.description: After the first clip, start moving right to the crux of the route after the third clip. Head back left and up to a short crack and another short crux stepping left then up to the anchors.
content.location: This is currently the farthest right route on the wall. From the huge roof, head right along 4th class ledges until you get to a cozy ledge with a dead tree.

content.description:
Start far down and right of the giant roof that

Mourning Glory

is on. Start up poor quality, broken rock for a high first clip. Clear an easy bulge to much better rock. Using long draws on the second and third clip will help reduce drag on this wandering route. Traverse left to where the harder climbing starts. Big holds and big moves lead you to the crux at the last clip.
content.location:
Start on a ledge lower down and right than the ledge where

Mourning Glory

starts. You might want to set up a natural anchor for your belayer, since the ledge is pretty sketchy.
